headline: Saudi Aramco makes an eye-popping $160bn in profit

main.description: A Saudi Aramco employee and a photographer walk at the Khurais oil field, during a tour for journalists, 150 km east-northeast of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Monday, June 28, 2021. Aramco officials said, Khurais has a flare minimization program and a cogeneration plant to generate electricity from waste heat to reduce emissions. (AP Photo/Amr Nabil)

description: And you thought the supermajors had a good year

children.data: The world’s energy supermajors had a bountiful 2022. ExxonMobil, the largest of the private-sector giants, reported a record annual net profit of $56bn, after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent oil prices soaring. Mouth-watering—unless you are Saudi Aramco, in which case it’s peanuts. Last year the desert kingdom’s oil giant brought in some $160bn of net income, the most by any company in corporate history.
To stay on top of the biggest stories in business and technology, sign up to the

bodyText:
The world’s energy supermajors had a bountiful 2022. ExxonMobil, the largest of the private-sector giants, reported a record annual net profit of $56bn, after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent oil prices soaring. Mouth-watering—unless you are Saudi Aramco, in which case it’s peanuts. Last year the desert kingdom’s oil giant brought in some $160bn of net income, the most by any company in corporate history.■
To stay on top of the biggest stories in business and technology, sign up to the Bottom Line, our weekly subscriber-only newsletter.

print.headline: Saudi Aramco makes an eye-popping $160bn in profit

_metadata.title: Aramco’s princely sums - Saudi Aramco makes an eye-popping $160bn in profit | Business | The Economist
_metadata.shareSnippet: Aramco’s princely sums – Saudi Aramco makes an eye-popping $160bn in profit
_metadata.headline: Saudi Aramco makes an eye-popping $160bn in profit
author: The Economist
_metadata.articleBody:
The world’s energy supermajors had a bountiful 2022. ExxonMobil, the largest of the private-sector giants, reported a record annual net profit of $56bn, after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent oil prices soaring. Mouth-watering—unless you are Saudi Aramco, in which case it’s peanuts. Last year the desert kingdom’s oil giant brought in some $160bn of net income, the most by any company in corporate history.■
To stay on top of the biggest stories in business and technology, sign up to the Bottom Line, our weekly subscriber-only newsletter.
